Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Child Safety Seat with Time-of-Crash Sensor for Passive Safety Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to create a novel child safety seat technology that reduces the number of child deaths and injuries resulting from motor vehicle crashes. Impacts beyond saving lives and preventing injuries include reducing healthcare costs and advancing the field of vehicle occupant kinematics research. The direct societal benefit of the proposed advanced child safety seat technology is that, if successful, it will improve the effectiveness of child safety seats and reduce the likelihood of head injuries.

The proposed project will develop an innovative sensing mechanism mounted in a child safety seat that determines when to deploy time-of-crash protections within the child seat itself. Children riding in child safety seats are presently not protected by advanced time-of-crash technologies such as frontal airbags and belt pre-tensioners. The implementation of this mechanism will be extremely challenging given the cost and reliability constraints imposed by the market. The societal and commercial rewards for success are substantial because the technology would represent a key performance and market discriminator. It is expected that the fatality risk for children protected by time-of-crash technologies triggered by the proposed system will be lowered by about 12%.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Minnesota HealthSolutions (MHS) developed and evaluated an innovative sensor that can be designed into a child safety seat to sense the state of the vehicle active crash protection systems.  The utility of this new “trigger” (time-of-crash sensor) is that it allows a child safety seat to provide advanced time-of-crash passive occupant protections to children that will substantially improve safety in motor vehicle crashes.

 

The long-term goal for this line of research is a product that reduces child injuries and deaths from motor vehicle crashes. Child safety seats, when properly used, reduce the chance of death for children significantly. However, further advances to improve the performance of these important safety tools are needed as motor vehicle crashes remain a leading cause of death and serious head injury for children in the United States. While child safety seats and the features that they offer have evolved over the past few decades, their purpose has remained to link the child as tightly as possible to the vehicle to enable the child to benefit from the vehicle’s energy absorption during a crash. There are presently no child safety seats offering time-of-crash protections.

 

Adult passengers are often protected by time-of-crash technologies such as seat belt pretensioners that are deployed when sensors mounted at the front and sides of the vehicle detect the onset of a serious crash.  Recent studies have suggested that it may be possible to improve kinematics and reduce injuries to rear seat occupants in frontal collisions by incorporating shoulder-belt force-limiting and pretensioning technologies into rear seat restraints. Most of this data has centered on the evaluation of protection for adult occupants; no data exist to understand if the protection afforded by these advanced systems extend to children in child safety seats. Child safety seats do not presently offer time-of-crash technologies because they do not have an interface to the crash sensors that are necessarily mounted on the vehicle itself. Any technological advance designed to reduce slack should result in improvement in protection. 

 

The developed sensor determines when the vehicle time-of-crash passive safety system is activated by the vehicle crash sensors and uses this information to trigger time-of-crash protections, such as a child seat harness pretensioner in the child safety seat itself. A harness pretensioner tightens the 5-point harness restraining the child in the child safety seat at the time-of-crash. Removing any slack in the harness by pretensioning it at the time-of-crash will substantially decrease the likelihood of the child’s head contacting surfaces in the vehicle and reduce the rate of serious injuries and death during crashes. Seat belt pretensioning systems for adult passengers have been observed to lower the fatality risk.

 

This completed phase I program achieved two research aims: 1) designed, built, and evaluated the novel sensor/trigger mechanism and 2) computationally evaluated a time-of-crash child safety seat harness pretensioning system. The completed time-of-crash sensor and trigger design was analyzed for its ability to accurately sense the vehicle time-of-crash safety system deployment and its manufacturability.  Manufacturing cost, size and weight, and durability of the design were evaluated.  

 

A complete Finite Element Model was designed to simulate a crash with a pretensioner firing at a number of times in the crash cycle. The effects on head, chest, and pelvis acceleration, head excursion, and chest deflection were analyzed and compared.
